bibl.title: Letter from Avery S. Hoyt to Philip Showalter Hench, December 30, 1944

div1.p: Hoyt provides information on how to protect Building No. 1 from the effects of weathering and the attack of termites.

div1.head: Letter from Avery S. Hoyt to Philip Showalter Hench, December 30, 1944
div1.opener:
File under A
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH ADMINISTRATION
BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY AND PLANT QUARANTINE
WASHINGTON, D. C.
DEC 30 1944
(25)
Lt. Col. Philip S. Hench, M. C.
Chief of the Medical Service
Army & Navy General Hospital
Hot Springs National Park, Arkansas
Dear Colonel Hench:
div1.p:
We are much interested in your letter of December 6 and the enclosed
reprint of your article entitled, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever,” and
hope that our suggestions will aid you in restoring and saving the one
remaining building that commemorates this historic endeavor. It ap-
pears from your article that Building Number One which housed the in-
fected bedding and clothing used in the early tests, is the one which
is still standing and which is deteriorating from the effects of
weathering and the attack of termites. Quite likely both the drywood
and the subterranean species of termites are concerned. We are enclos-
ing two publications containing information on these insects.

In Farmers' Bulletin No. 1472, on page 5, you will find information
concerning the habits of drywood termites and, on pages 17 and 18,
measures recommended for their control. The tunnels of drywood ter-
mites can be effectively dusted with Paris green powder or the wood
saturated with liquid orthodichlorobenzene. Recent studies indicate
that a 5 percent solution of pentachlorphenol is more effective than is
the orthodichlorobenzene. A list of names of companies which handle
these chemicals is enclosed for your convenience.

To insure a thorough treatment where drywood termites are concerned,
the dry Paris green may be dusted into the tunnels and then, after a
week or more, the entire woodwork should be thoroughly sprayed two or
three times, with the pentachlorphenol. Such a treatment will be bene-
ficial in controlling wood rotting fungi, as well as termites. The chemi-
cal is carried in a relatively clean oil over which paint can be applied
to the dried wood if desired. Precautions which should be taken while
handling this chemical will be found on pages 35 and 36 of the enclosed
Farmers' Bulletin 1911. This bulletin also contains our latest informa-
tion concerning subterranean termite control.

In restoring the building it is important that careful consideration
be given to the sanitation methods, described on pages 33 and 34 of
Farmers' Bulletin 1911, which are of importance with relation to sub-
terranean termite control. In restoring the underpinning it is
2-Lt. Col. Philip S. Hench, M. C.- DEC 30 1944
recommended that either pressure-treated wood or metal shields or both
be used, such as are illustrated in figure 29 on page 30. If pressure-
treated wood is not obtainable, a certain amount of protection can be had
by soaking well-seasoned prefabricated posts in the 5% solution of penta-
chlorphenol for a period of 1 to 3 weeks. If metal shields are unobtain-
able it might be well to consider poisoning the soil surrounding each of
the wooden posts to keep termites from reaching the posts and extending
their tubes over them to untreated wood above.

FOR VICTORY
BUY
UNITED
STATES
WAR
BONDS
AND
STAMPS

DDT has not been sufficiently tested by us as yet to warrant making
definite recommendations concerning its use for termite control. We
feel that the above measures will prove to be adequate.

If we can be of further assistance, do not hesitate to call on us at
any time.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Avery S Hoyt
Acting Chief of Bureau Enclosures - 3
